Award.AwardTitle: From Carbon-Rich Bowls to Nanobelts and Warped Nanographene: Self-Assembly and Metal Ion Intercalation Upon Multi-Charging
Award.AbstractNarration:
This NSF award by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Marina A. Petrukhina, a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at the State University of New York at Albany. This project is to explore a diverse set of novel nanocarbon materials ranging from carbon bowls to nanobelts and warped nanographene. Studies of the addition of several electrons by novel nanostructured systems may improve our understanding of their fundamental properties. The research may also expand the applications of carbon-rich materials in several technological fields ranging from electronics to energy storage. This research lies at the interface of organometallic, supramolecular and nanochemistry and provides unique educational and research experiences for graduate and undergraduate students at the University at Albany. The project is designed to engage the students in a modern interdisciplinary research in synthetic, structural and materials chemistry and thus, to prepare them for successful careers in chemistry.

This research includes a broad fundamental investigation of chemical reduction processes occurring on novel curved and strained nanocarbon systems with different structural topologies ranging from carbon-rich bowl-shaped polyarenes to nanobelts and warped nanographene sheets. This diverse set of structurally well-defined carbon materials provides unique opportunities to study their multi-electron uptake properties at the molecular level. Specifically, investigations of the structural consequences of adding multiple electrons to the curved and bent surfaces are being pursued. Studies of alkali metal intercalation and self-assembly trends related to the non-planar and highly charged carbanions is also studied. As a result, this research may improve our fundamental understanding of the redox behavior and electron transport properties of carbonaceous nanomaterials having different structures and nanosized dimensions. The project may assist in describing alkali metal ion intercalation in between non-planar carbon surfaces, which is important for the advancement of carbon-based anode materials in energy storage devices. This fundamental research may advance the materials chemistry applications of curved carbon-rich polyarenes and enhance education opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students at the University at Albany. The education plan targets training of the next generation of materials chemists, including women and minorities, and is well integrated with the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits

With the funds provided by the National Science Foundation CHE-1608628 award, a broad fundamental program to investigate the stepwise chemical reduction processes of non-planar and strained molecular nanocarbons with different structural topologies has been established at the Department of Chemistry, University at Albany, NY. This diverse set of structurally well-defined carbon materials ranging from carbon π-bowls to nanobelts and nanographenes provided unique opportunities to uncover their multi-electron uptake properties at the molecular level. This program systematically explored structural and electronic transformations, alkali metal intercalation and self-assembly of novel curved π-systems upon stepwise electron charging. During the award period, the developed efficient synthetic protocols allowed isolation of a wide-ranging set of novel phase-pure supramolecular products followed by their full characterization using a combination of X-ray diffraction, spectroscopic and theoretical tools. Overall, this program has advanced our fundamental understanding of the redox properties and supramolecular behavior of various nanostructured carbon-rich materials with different topologies and broad-ranging reduced states and provided new insights for their applications.

The results have been reported in 30 research manuscripts published since 2016 in a variety of peer-reviewed scientific journals. Among those are Angew. Chem. (9), JACS (1), Chem. Sci. (2), Chem. Commun. (2), Chem. Eur. J. (4), Org. Chem. Front. and Organometallics (3) manuscripts, several of which were selected as Very Important Papers and highlighted on journal covers, one highlighted in JACS Spotlights. We also contributed a comprehensive review (Acc. Chem. Res. 2018) and an invited Frontier paper (Dalton Trans. 2019). The results were broadly disseminated by the PI and graduate students at multiple National and Regional ACS meetings, as well as at several international conferences.

Broader Impacts

This fundamental research program facilitated elucidation of alkali metal ion intercalation patterns in non-planar π-carbon host matrices, which is important for the search and design of new carbon-based anode materials for Li-ion and Na-ion batteries. Therefore, this program have advanced the development of materials chemistry of curved carbon-rich scaffolds and promoted applications of novel alkali metal-doped carbonaceous materials in the technologically-important field of energy storage. Using the results obtained in this experimental program, the PI has also participated in two successful NSF-MRI grant applications (as a co-PI) that were awarded and allowed the acquisition of two major instruments, 500 MHz NMR Spectrometer (2017-2020) and Mass Spectrometer-Coupled Thermogravimetric Analyzer System (2019-2022). These new additions have greatly improved the research infrastructure at the Department of Chemistry, University at Albany. Both instruments have been used in research and training of our graduate and undergraduate students.

In the course of the above research activities, an educational program was created for training young chemists who became proficient in organic and inorganic synthesis, crystal growth, X-ray diffraction and variable spectroscopic techniques. The program participants also developed good writing and presentation skills as well as understanding of current needs and challenges in applications of carbon-based nanomaterials. This project has been used to train several graduate and undergraduate students, and one postdoctoral associate. Over the reported period six students have successfully graduated (3 Ph.D. and 3 M.S. students, including 3 female scientists). Two Ph.D. students were recognized by the very competitive University at Albany Distinguished Doctoral Dissertation Awards (2017 and 2020). All graduate students participating in this NSF-supported program co-authored multiple research manuscripts and delivered presentations at the local and National ACS meetings (including virtual ACS meetings in 2020). Several graduate students received university, state and national awards that include the prestigious University at Albany President's Award for Sustainability Leadership, 2016; the Future Leaders Speaker, the ENY ACS Series, Albany, NY, 2017; the ACS Division of Inorganic Chemistry Student Travel Award, 2020. Overall, this program made its major impact on the enhancement of educational and research experiences for graduate and undergraduate students at the University at Albany by engaging them into a modern cross-disciplinary research program, and thus preparing them for their successful careers in science.
